Content: Prince Estabrook memorial in front of  on Lexington Green in Lexington, Massachusetts.  Prince Estabrook, who was wounded in the  was the first Black casualty of the Revolutionary War.

Name: p
Content: As historian Christopher L. Brown put it, slavery -had never been on the agenda in a serious way before,- but the Revolution -forced it to be a public question from there forward.-  In the first two decades after the American Revolution, state legislatures and individuals took actions to free slaves, in part based on revolutionary ideals. Northern states passed new constitutions that contained language about equal rights or specifically abolished slavery; some states, such as New York and New Jersey, where slavery was more widespread, passed laws by the end of the 18th century to abolish slavery by a gradual method.  By 1804, all the northern states had passed laws outlawing slavery, either immediately or over time.  In New York, the last slaves were freed in 1827.  Indentured servitude (temporary slavery), which had been widespread in the colonies (Half the population of Philadelphia had once been bonded servants) dropped dramatically, and disappeared by 1800.  An  sailed through Congress with little opposition.  President  supported it, and it went in effect on January 1, 1808.   and  each helped found manumission societies.  No southern state abolished slavery, but for a period individual owners could free their slaves by personal decision, often providing for manumission in wills but sometimes filing deeds or court papers to free individuals. Numerous slaveholders who freed their slaves cited revolutionary ideals in their documents; others freed slaves as a reward for service. Records also suggest that some slaveholders were freeing their own mixed-race children, born into slavery to slave mothers.  The number of free blacks as a proportion of the black population in the upper South increased from less than 1 percent to nearly 10 percent between 1790 and 1810 as a result of these actions.

Name: p
Content: Thousands of free Blacks in the northern states fought in the state militias and Continental Army.  In the south, both sides offered freedom to slaves who would perform military service.  Roughly 20,000 slaves fought in the American Revolution.

Name: p
Content: Shortly after the Revolution, the  was established, by  and  (who had been George Washington's chief engineer).  Both Cutler and Putnam came from  New England.  The Puritans strongly believed that slavery was morally wrong.  Their influence on the issue of slavery was long-lasting, and this was provided significantly greater impetus by the Revolution.  The Northwest Territory (which became Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Illinois, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota) doubled the size of the United States, and it was established at the insistence of Cutler and Putnam as -free soil- - no slavery.  This was to prove crucial a few decades later.  Had those states been slave states, and their electoral votes gone to Abraham Lincoln's main opponent, Lincoln would not have become president.  The  would not have been fought.  Even if it eventually had been, the North might well have lost.

Name: p
Content: The democratic ideals of the Revolution inspired changes in the roles of women.

Name: p
Content: The concept of  was inspired by this period and reflects the importance of . It assumed that a successful republic rested upon the virtue of its citizens. Women were considered to have the essential role of instilling their children with values conducive to a healthy republic. During this period, the wife's relationship with her husband also became more liberal, as love and affection instead of obedience and subservience began to characterize the ideal marital relationship. In addition, many women contributed to the war effort through fundraising and running family businesses without their husbands.

Name: a
title: Revolutionary
Content: Republicanism as the dominant American ideology

Name: p
Content: The traditional constraints gave way to more liberal conditions for women. Patriarchy faded as an ideal; young people had more freedom to choose their spouses and more often used birth control to regulate the size of their families. Society emphasized the role of mothers in child rearing, especially the patriotic goal of raising republican children rather than those locked into aristocratic value systems. There was more permissiveness in child-rearing. Patriot women married to Loyalists who left the state could get a divorce and obtain control of the ex-husband's property.Whatever gains they had made, however, women still found themselves subordinated, legally and socially, to their husbands, disfranchised and usually with only the role of mother open to them. But, some women earned livelihoods as midwives and in other roles in the community not originally recognized as significant by men.

Name: p
Content: expressed to her husband, the president, the desire of women to have a place in the new republic: -I desire you would remember the Ladies, and be more generous and favourable to them than your ancestors. Do not put such unlimited power into the hands of the Husbands.-

Name: p
Content: The Revolution sparked a discussion on the rights of woman and an environment favorable to women's participation in politics. Briefly the possibilities for women's rights were highly favorable, but a backlash led to a greater rigidity that excluded women from politics.

Name: p
Content: For more than thirty years, however, the 1776  gave the vote to -all inhabitants- who had a certain level of wealth, including unmarried women and blacks (not married women because they could not own property separately from their husbands), until in 1807, when that state legislature passed a bill interpreting the constitution to mean universal , excluding paupers.

Name: p
Content: The American Revolution has a central place in the American memory as the story of the nation's founding. It is covered in the schools, memorialized by a , and commemorated in innumerable monuments. George Washington's estate at  was one of the first national pilgrimages for tourists and attracted 10,000 visitors a year by the 1850s.

Name: p
Content: The Revolution became a matter of contention in the 1850s in the debates leading to the  (1861–1865), as spokesmen of both the  and the  claimed that their region was the true custodian of the legacy of 1776.  The  in 1976 came a year after the American withdrawal from the , and speakers stressed the themes of renewal and rebirth based on a restoration of traditional values.

Name: p
Content: Today, more than 100  are protected and maintained by the government.  The  alone owns and maintains more than 50 battlefield parks and sites related to the Revolution. The  preserves almost 700 acres of battlefield land in six states.
